intro: Heteranthelium aleppicum, commonly known as the Aleppo liverwort, is a type of liverwort found in moist, shaded environments. It belongs to the family Porellaceae and is characterized by its small, closely packed leaves. The plant exhibits a thalloid structure, which is a flat, leaf-like body that lacks true roots, stems, and leaves. It reproduces through spores, which are released from specialized structures called sporophytes. Heteranthelium aleppicum is often found on rocky surfaces or in damp soil, contributing to the ecological diversity of its habitat.
